name: Ragi Idli
history: Ragi Idli is a healthier variation of the traditional South Indian idli. It incorporates ragi flour, also known as finger millet, known for its rich nutritional content.
description: Ragi Idli is a nutritious and delicious alternative to regular idlis, made using ragi flour mixed with rice and urad dal. These idlis are soft, fluffy, and rich in fiber and calcium.

ingredients.quantity: as required for grinding and batter consistency

instructions.title: Soak and Grind
instructions.description: Soak the urad dal, idli rice, and fenugreek seeds in water for 4-6 hours. Grind them along with ragi flour to a smooth batter, adding water as needed.

instructions.title: Ferment the Batter
instructions.description: Transfer the batter to a mixing bowl, add salt, and mix well. Allow it to ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours until it doubles in volume.

instructions.title: Steam the Idlis
instructions.description: Grease the idli molds. Pour the batter into the molds and steam in an idli steamer or cooker for 10-15 minutes, or until the idlis are cooked and fluffy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Ragi Idlis hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

tips: Ensure the batter is not too thick; it should have a pouring consistency.
Fermentation time may vary depending on the climate; warmer places ferment batter faster.
variations: Add grated vegetables or chopped greens to the batter for extra nutrition.
Experiment with different proportions of ragi and rice for a change in texture and taste.

storage.shelfLife: Ragi Idli batter can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store the batter in an airtight container and refrigerate.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat idlis in a steamer or microwave until warm.
presentationTips: Garnish with grated coconut or a sprig of curry leaves for a traditional touch.
